While big business often continues in
its attempts to roll back the clock, most
enlightexed folks agree that labor in this
country has some basic rights, such as the
right to have its grievances objectively
heard.
It is a persisting irony, then, that this
University--supposedly a center for enlight.mment--refuses to grant this basic right to
its employees. Last year's firing of Marge
Mareck, a veteran secretary who complained to the National Labor Relations
Board about her salary, revealed the depth
of employee discontent at JHU: an employees association was formed, demonstrations were held, and a survey of employees
indicated strong dissatisfaction with pay,
hours, and employer treatment.
The University's subsequent actions
made clear its high-handed and arbitrary
attitude toward its employees. The issue
was not primarily whether Mrs. Mareck was
justified in seeking a raise, or whether she
was no longer working effectively, as her
superior, Dr. Galambos, charged in firing
her. What is important is that the University repeatedly rejected Mrs. Mareck's
please for an objective grievance hearing.
Her case was reviewed privately by various
administration members, and her final
dismissal was approved singlehandedly by
Dean Suskind. In addition, the University
refused to recognize the newly-formed
Johns Hopkins Employees Association, and
made no response to that group's proposal

for an objective grievance procedure. The
existing procedure states only that "any
staff member has the right...to present any
personal concern or dissatisfaction regarding his or her employment, and have it
considered on its merits," but sets no
specific guidelines after that. The supervisor of an employee with a grievance can
meet with administration officials, without
the employee in attendance. While a
University "personnel committee" is currently looking into revising the existing
grievance procedure, the committee has
refused to include any employees as
members. The JHEA's proposal laid out
specific stages of bilateral discussion.
Last year the administration ignored
the Student Council's resolution of support
for the JHEA proposal. This year the
administration has begun diplomatic relations in a more emphatic style, rejecting
the proposed grievance procedure outright.
Administrators have refused to meet with
any employee claiming to be a JHEA
representative, and one employee was told
privately that her group's best bet is to
bargain through the Janitors' Collective
Bargaining Unit at Hopkins.
Another
employee described an encounter with the
administration as "like trying to talk to
Exxon."
Big business, it appears, is still trying
to roll back the clock, right here at Exxon
University. It's time JHU gave its employ-

ees a fair shake.

Neighborhood Crime Watch
In an effort to deter criminals from the Homewood
community, more than 30 volunteers have been patrolling the
streets of the neighborhood as part of the Greater Homewood
Neighborhood Crime Watch which began in the fall of 1979.
Each evening, five patrollers cover the area between 33
and 25th streets, Barclay St. and Maryland Ave., watching for
possible criminal activity. If the patrollers, who work either
on foot or in cars, observe anything suspicious, they report it by
CB radio to the base station in the basement of the North Charles
General Hospital which employs another 30 volunteers.
The volunteers at the base station then notify the
Baltimore City Police who then investigate the incident. So far
the watch has resulted in about 30 arrests, including apprehensions for breaking and entering, vandalism, and larceny.
Volunteers vary in age from the low 20's to the 60s. Most
are professionals and college graduates. The Crime Watch currently employs two Hopkins graduate students.
Robert Whitby, president of the Greater Homewood
Community Corporation estimates that 30 to 50 percent of the
volunteers are previous victims of crime, while many of the others
are neighbors of victims. Whitby feels that the Crime Watch's
greatest accomplishment has been to deter criminals from trying
to commit crimes in the neighborhood.
The Crime Watch, now a standing committee of the
Greater Homewood Community Corporation has recently received a donation of 500 dollars from Thhns Hopkins University
for radio equipment and the Crime Watch is currently trying to
coordinate its efforts with Campus Security at Hopkins.

University--supposedly a center for enlight.mment--refuses to grant this basic right to
its employees. Last year's firing of Marge
Mareck, a veteran secretary who complained to the National Labor Relations
Board about her salary, revealed the depth
of employee discontent at JHU: an employees association was formed, demonstrations were held, and a survey of employees
indicated strong dissatisfaction with pay,
hours, and employer treatment.
The University's subsequent actions
made clear its high-handed and arbitrary
attitude toward its employees. The issue
was not primarily whether Mrs. Mareck was
justified in seeking a raise, or whether she
was no longer working effectively, as her
superior, Dr. Galambos, charged in firing
her. What is important is that the University repeatedly rejected Mrs. Mareck's
please for an objective grievance hearing.
Her case was reviewed privately by various
administration members, and her final
dismissal was approved singlehandedly by
Dean Suskind. In addition, the University
refused to recognize the newly-formed
Johns Hopkins Employees Association, and
made no response to that group's proposal

for an objective grievance procedure. The
existing procedure states only that "any
staff member has the right...to present any
personal concern or dissatisfaction regarding his or her employment, and have it
considered on its merits," but sets no
specific guidelines after that. The supervisor of an employee with a grievance can
meet with administration officials, without
the employee in attendance. While a
University "personnel committee" is currently looking into revising the existing
grievance procedure, the committee has
refused to include any employees as
members. The JHEA's proposal laid out
specific stages of bilateral discussion.
Last year the administration ignored
the Student Council's resolution of support
for the JHEA proposal. This year the
administration has begun diplomatic relations in a more emphatic style, rejecting
the proposed grievance procedure outright.
Administrators have refused to meet with
any employee claiming to be a JHEA
representative, and one employee was told
privately that her group's best bet is to
bargain through the Janitors' Collective
Bargaining Unit at Hopkins.
Another
employee described an encounter with the
administration as "like trying to talk to
Exxon."
Big business, it appears, is still trying
to roll back the clock, right here at Exxon
University. It's time JHU gave its employ-

ees a fair shake.

Neighborhood Crime Watch
In an effort to deter criminals from the Homewood
community, more than 30 volunteers have been patrolling the
streets of the neighborhood as part of the Greater Homewood
Neighborhood Crime Watch which began in the fall of 1979.
Each evening, five patrollers cover the area between 33
and 25th streets, Barclay St. and Maryland Ave., watching for
possible criminal activity. If the patrollers, who work either
on foot or in cars, observe anything suspicious, they report it by
CB radio to the base station in the basement of the North Charles
General Hospital which employs another 30 volunteers.
The volunteers at the base station then notify the
Baltimore City Police who then investigate the incident. So far
the watch has resulted in about 30 arrests, including apprehensions for breaking and entering, vandalism, and larceny.
Volunteers vary in age from the low 20's to the 60s. Most
are professionals and college graduates. The Crime Watch currently employs two Hopkins graduate students.
Robert Whitby, president of the Greater Homewood
Community Corporation estimates that 30 to 50 percent of the
volunteers are previous victims of crime, while many of the others
are neighbors of victims. Whitby feels that the Crime Watch's
greatest accomplishment has been to deter criminals from trying
to commit crimes in the neighborhood.
The Crime Watch, now a standing committee of the
Greater Homewood Community Corporation has recently received a donation of 500 dollars from Thhns Hopkins University
for radio equipment and the Crime Watch is currently trying to
coordinate its efforts with Campus Security at Hopkins.

show only one per week, thereby increasing the audience and thus the profits.
